title: 7 Simple Ways to Fix Live Photos Not Saving on FaceTime

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the gray cog icon. If you're using FaceTime on a Mac, open FaceTime's menu and click Preferences . All participating FaceTime users must have Live Photos enabled to take or save photos.

steps.title: Tap FaceTime.
steps.content: Tap FaceTime . You can find this underneath Messages . If you're using a Mac, skip this step.

steps.title: Toggle off "FaceTime Live Photos".
steps.content: Toggle off "FaceTime Live Photos". You may need to scroll down to find this option. On Mac, this will look like Allow Live Photos to be captured during video calls .

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the gray cog icon.

steps.title: Tap General.
steps.content: Tap General . You can find this below Screen Time .

steps.title: Tap iPhone Storage.
steps.content: Tap iPhone Storage . A new page will open with a detailed chart of your iPhone's storage. You'll see the available space in the top-right corner of the chart. If you don't have space on your iPhone, you won't be able to save any more photos. To free up storage space, you can transfer files from your iPhone to your computer. You can also use a cloud service, such as iCloud or Google Photos to store your photos and videos.

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the gray cog icon.

steps.title: Tap Screen Time.
steps.content: Tap Screen Time . You can find this underneath Focus .

steps.title: Tap Content & Privacy Restrictions.
steps.content: Tap Content & Privacy Restrictions . This is below Always Allowed .

steps.title: Tap Allowed Apps.
steps.content: Tap Allowed Apps . You can find this towards the top of the page.

steps.title: Enable "Camera" and "FaceTime."
steps.content: Enable "Camera" and "FaceTime." The switches should be green.

steps.title: Open the Settings app.
steps.content: Open the Settings app. This is the gray cog icon.

steps.title: Tap FaceTime.
steps.content: Tap FaceTime . You can find this underneath Messages .

steps.title: Toggle off "FaceTime".
steps.content: Toggle off "FaceTime". The switch will turn grey.

steps.title: Toggle on "FaceTime".
steps.content: Toggle on "FaceTime". The switch will turn green. Try to retake FaceTime photos.

steps.title: Restart your iPhone
steps.content: Restart your iPhone . Sometimes, a simple restart can fix basic issues. If your iPhone uses Face ID, press and hold the Volume Up button and Power button at the same time. Swipe to power off. Wait at least thirty seconds, and then power it on again. On iPhones with a home button, press and hold the side button. Slide to power off.

steps.title: Update your iPhone
steps.content: Update your iPhone . Keep your phone software up-to-date. Software updates include important bug fixes and, most times, stronger security features. Do the following: Go to Settings . Tap General . Tap Software Update . Tap Download and Install .

steps.title: Take a screenshot
steps.content: Take a screenshot instead. If all else fails, you can always take a screenshot to save FaceTime moments. You can also screen record on your iPhone to save any videos, but keep in mind you won't be able to record any of the audio. [1] X Research source to check
